text: 16oz can at CBC pours a garnet amber with some spitty, white head. Nose of malt, spruce, heavy pine sol. Flavor is too bitter, malt and orange too. Harsh on the finish.

16oz can won during free beer week. Poured a deep copper body under a smaller to average sized foamy off white head. Aroma is caramel, molasses, toffee, rye seeds, medium toast, bitter citrus and pine. Medium to fuller body with stronger carbonation. Flavor starts off with loads of caramel and toffee in the front followed buy bitter citrus and rye spice. Really excellent beer.
Tap at La Cumbre, Albuquerque. Colour is clear dark orange with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Rye, dryness, hops and malts. Very "full" and strong flavours.

16 oz can. Pours a medium, well retained, tiny bubbled dark ivory head, with extensive lacing, over clear copper (SRM 18) body.......nose is rye, pine, resin, mild toffee/caramel, balance to the hops........taste is moderately sweet, with toffee/caramel tones, rye, with rye spice, pine, resin, licorice, finishing with medium, lingering bitterness, balance slightly to the hops......mouth feel, slightly sticky, light of medium body, slight alcohol, mild astringency, high carbonation. This is an interesting Specialty Grain beer. The rye comes in nicely, adds spice, and the hops were deftly handled. The aromas are a bit on the light side. BJCP 8/3/16/4/7

On tap, poured a clear reddish hue w/ frothy white slowly diminishing head. Sweet and spicy malty aromas. Initial flavor is moderate sweet w/ a bold bitter finish. Tastes are rye, grassy hop, and bready malt. Full bodied.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma - has a little oakiness, some piney and pungent hop oil, with a touch of caramel.
Appearance - the body is a hazy amber, and the head is beige and 1". The head just sits and sits, hardly ever dissipating. Not much lacing, but some.
Taste - is a rye malt, with Pacific Northwest variety hops. Mostly of a spruce nature, there is also some pungency. Seems like a meeting of the 3 Cs - Columbia, Centennial, and Cascade. Balance is very nice, there is also a bit of caramel and some woodiness.
Palate - medium body, texture is very smooth - not oily, carbonation is average, and the finish is slightly bitter and pungent. Finish is of a medium length.
Can thanks to my Father-In-Law Dan: Poured Carmel orange and off white head. Dank hops and earth nose. Taste is nice sweet malts with earth hops.

Pint can. Caramel malt aroma with earthy rye and toasted malt notes as well as subtle pine and citrus hops. Pours deep red colored with about a finger of tan head that has good retention and decent lacing. Starts with caramel malt sweetness as well as toasted malt and earthy remote flavors. Finishes dry with a good amount of pine and citrus hop bitterness that's not at all overpowering. Excellent red!
16 ounce can thanks to 	wchesser. Big amber red with some citrus and pine notes. Caramel.

Canned. Amber with a big sudsy beige head that has crazy lacing and great retention. The aroma is nutty and spicy. The taste, like the aroma, is nutty and spicy too, with some toffee and piney hops backing it all up.. The palate is medium. Finished long and dry with a lingering spicy hop bitterness. Overall: Decent.

Type: 16-oz. draft
Glass: Clear willybecher pint glass
From: La Cumbre Brewery in Albuquerque, N.M.
Price: $5
Purchased: May 5, 2016
Consumed: May 5, 2016
Misc.: N/A 

Was looking forward to this one. Decided if I liked it enough, I might even take a 4-pack home, but it would have to be better than Elevated IPA (it wasnt). First time I have heard of this one. 

Poured an auburn, caramel, clear color with two fingers of khaki tan, frothy head. Light bubbles coming up from the bottom of the glass. Very good amount of semi-layered foamy lacing. Good retention. (Sight - 4.25)

Smelled floral hops, Citra, orange blossom, caramel, rye, sweetened iced tea and peach. (Smell - 4.25)

Tasted rye, caramel, sweetened iced tea, Citra, floral, caramel, earthy, slight nuts and toffee. (Taste - 4.00)

Medium body. Creamy texture. Average carbonation. Long finish. (Overall - 4.00)

Liked this one a lot, probably more than I even thought. Would like to try it again some time. (Overall - 4.00)

4.08 91 A-

An amazing pour, from the can into a porter glass despite the request of a tumbler. Watching the liquid cascade into itself is like watching honey being decanted into the glass, then into the pillowy, soft foam that rises aggressively at the surface.
- The aroma is spicy with rye and malts, but the flavor is hops bold as well. As the head diminishes, the aroma becomes larger; caramel, biscuit and edgy rye spice with a mild and dreamy addition of clover in the flavor. Massive in experience, every attribute is delectable, from the moderate body to the mild and lightly bitter body.
-The lacing on the glass as I swallow the last bits of this delicious brew is consistent and gorgeous from the lip of the glass to the base, and if there was no reason to visit New Mexico before, there is nothing that could keep me away now. This is beautiful from aroma to finish. Ill be planning a vacation...when is the weather perfect in New Mexico?

Can.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark amber.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (caramel, toasted grain/seeds), moderately to heavily hoppy (resin, grapefruit), with a note of gum.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately to heavily bitter.

Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic, lightly to moderately astringent. 

A bit of a resin bomb, not a whole lot going on in the nose besides that, but its ok. Both too sour and too bitter in the mouth, and the astringency doesnt help either...unbalanced and brutish and thus hard to enjoy drinking very much. Not very good, with no elegance or finesse, just another "quantity over quality" overhopped American amber ale.

Can. Incredibly bright pine needles and wet grass in the nose, backed up by caramel and toasted rye. Flavor is a similar hop bomb: piney, floral, grapefruity goodness. Dry biscuits, sharp rye, and just enough dark malt sugars balance things out. Peppery hop resins dig into the tongue at the finish; moderate bitterness grips the back. Really great.
Pours reddish copper. Nose is citrus and floral hops with sone caramel malts. Taste follows. Very drinkable with great balance. Like a West Coast IPA with a nice malt backbone.

Can from wchesser -- cheers! This is interesting -- its both a malt bomb and a hop bomb, if thats even possible. The malt backbone is grainy and rustic from what Im guessing is mountains of rye malt, with some caramel sweetness too. Then theres a lot of general hop aroma towards the end that would probably taste a lot like an IPA if it wasnt for the lingering rye flavor. Great rye beer!

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a dark red with a thick off white head. Aroma of earthy hops, rye spices, bitter hops, caramel malt. Flavor of rich malt, earthy malt, rye spices, citrus hops. Malty, lightly spiced, hoppy too. Very hearty.
7/4/8/4/14 (3.7/5)

16 oz can. Pours clear ruby amber with a medium creamy off white head that slowly goes to a thin film and laces the glass.

The aroma is sweet rye malts with some fruit and some piney hops.

The flavor is sweet roasted rye grains and nutty caramel with some fruit and a big piney resiny bitterness. The mouthfeel is medium bodied with low carbonation.

Overall, a nice red rye IPA. A little on the sweet side for me.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2016 16 oz single can from the Craft Beer Cellar - Fort Collins. Clear ruby red appearance with a fluffy, khaki colored head. Aroma of pine, toasted grain, light citrus, light caramel malt and some rye spiciness. Similar flavor, rich, malty and lightly sweet with a medium hop bitterness powering through. Medium body with a light spicy rye, light dry finish. Smooth and easy to drink overall.

Deep but mostly clear Amber with a thick and foamy ivory head. Amazingly lovely aroma with floral resins and grapefruit zest, a touch of pine resin, sweet orange zest, more fresh leafy floral tones, and lots of Amber and boozy caramalts. Smooth and flavorful body thats warm but not boozy--bitter but not acidic--hoppy, but sublimely balanced. Lots of grapefruit zest and floral resins, a little pine, a touch tropical and juicy, with a lovely caramalt and Amber malt backbone.
On tap at brewery. Dark amber pour with small creamy head. Malty aroma with some hops on the backplane. Taste brings out the hops more, as well as the thicker, musty rye character. Close to an IRA.

Can sampled at GABF 2015 with Andrew, Ellen and Paul. Pours a deep amber red body with big white head and lacing. Nose is dank rye, herbal hop profile and fresh grass. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with notes of dank herb, funky grass, fresh pine hop profile and fresh citrus.

Can. Pours crystal clear reddish amber, medium creamy off-white head, nice lacing. Aroma is strong rye, caramel, pine, rye bread. Flavor is light plus sweet, light bitter, rye bread, grains, pine. Medium body. Interesting.
Can poured clear copper with an off-white head and thin lacing. Aromas of pine, rye bread, caramel, earthiness, and spice. Flavor is hop bitter. Yum.

Can courtesy of HenrikO. Thanks for the NE tick man! Pours hazy brownish red with a small reddish offwhite head that leaves some sparse trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is malty, tiny fruity, herbal and spicy with rye bread, caramel, toffee, grapefruit juice, mango, moist grass, pine needles, resin, black pepper corns and lemon zest. Taste is slightly sweet, bitter, fruity, herbal and spicy. Mouthfeel is round, astringent, slightly sticky and medium bodied. Finish is slightly sweet and bitter with sweet rye bread, caramel, burnt cookies, grapefruit juice, unripe tropical fruit, moist grass, pine needles, lemon balm, resin, apple skins, black pepper corns and lemon zest. Solid offering of a style I dont normally like. Enjoyable and shows skill!

From can at GABF 2015. Pour is roasted amber with a big white head and sticky lacing. Super hoppy - dank, grassy, lots of bread, spicy hoppy, and candied oranges in the aroma. Taste is candied grapefruits, bready, caramelly, lots of dank bud, grass, and oranges with a big bitter finish. Sticky body with high carbonation. Juicy and full-bodied. Good shit.

GABF 2015. Pretty clear amber orange appearance with a light brown head. Hoppy as fuck. Tons of pine and dank bud. A little caramel and nuttiness. Super spicy. Not overly bitter. One of the best amber ales Ive ever had. This was a fucking treat and one of my favorites of the festival.
A taste from a friend (tap) @ Backstreet Grill, Albuquerque. Pours clear amber with a medium head. Aroma is fruity malts. Flavor is fruity malts and hops. Nice.

Wow, this is a seriously malty-sweet rye beer. Its got a fairly serious rye spice to it, and very serious piney hops, with a bitterness that lingers for a long time. The malt and sweetness is a bit much for me, so its not my favorite rye beer ever, but it is a very good one.

Can shared at the July MDF tasting. Clear dark red, thin creamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of caramel, grain, earthy and tropical hops, strong rye. The taste is strong rye, earthy and piney hops, caramel malt. Medium bodied, strong lingering bitterness.
Brown, reddish pour, nice lacy white foam. Aroma is spicy, rye, piney hops. Taste is piney hops, slightly bitter, spicy rye. Medium body, high carbonation. Solid rye beer. Great hop aroma.
Amber colored pour, off white head. Nice spicy, hoppy red ale here. Good citrusy notes, resin, light caramel, some fruit.

Can in Santa Fe. Pours a deep red amber, off white / tan head. Aroma is pine, citrus, rye, spices, malt, dank. Flavor is dank citrus hops, pine, rye, caramel, more hops. Big flavor from a hoppy red rye, nice.
From can and earlier at the Beermongers during CBC 2015. Lots of tart citrus hops, some really balanced rye flavors, and a hint of maltiness. Enjoy this.
Tap at Horse Brass. Aroma is good, very hoppy, lots of pine. Sticky. Taste is not so exciting, but still has a decent jammy fruitiness. Hops are not so strong. Nice though.
22oz bomber. Red orange hued brown. Off white beige head. Chewy rye, legit hop tones. Really solid offering. Great balance. Bold, but integrates the rye well.

Nice tan head, lasting, solid lace.Clear, deep amber ruby colored brew. Juicy, earthy nose, piny. Medium bodied, nice, slightly prickly carbonation, lil oily. Caramel malts backed by some fruity, piny hops and well done. Little bit of dankyness and resin with a nicely dried but sweet malt profile. Nice finish, lasting, nice bite, wicked Amber brew, enjoyable. Thanks Kevin!

Tap at brewpub
pours dark red hue with a soapy off white head and good lacing. Nose is hoppy and equallget much Dont get much of the rye. Flavors exhibit the rye morebthan the nose would suggest. Hops are there but add sweetness. Not overly bitter but well balanced. Solid yet I did expect more hop bitterness.

tap a few times, finally brought a 4 pack home. pours a deep ed with a yellow hued head. sweet candy, pine with bubble gum in the nose. sure, this has a big hop profile, but the malt is what im after. sweet, malty goodness here: cotton candy mixes with the pine notes very well. creamy mouthfeel with a nice lingering light caramel and citrus pine.
Received in trade. Got my New Mexico tick. Surprised how few rates are on here. I would call this a deep ruby IIPA.
draft at brewery, clean light and some rye flavors, a little of that grainy spice they have. other than that, your run of the mill red beer.
Beer #65 of NM 100. Nice fruity hops that mixes really well with the spicy rye character. Pineapple aroma. Flavor is a little bit soapy.

Tap @ Brewery. Pours rusty red with quickly dissipating lace and head. Hops, spice, toasted and caramel malt in the aroma. Nice balance of malt sweetness and hop dryness. The 7.3% ABV and 80 BUs are fully harmonized. Overall, a nice hoppy red ale with caramel backbone.
